channel.title: VB.NET Logica
channel.description:
I have to write a program that asks a 5-letter-word input to the user. All the possible combinations of 3-letter-words made with the 5 letters of the the user input have to be displayed.
I can't seem to get my head around the logica to do it. I'm now using randoms until the I have all the words. But this is far from efficient and doesn't work correctly when multiple letters of the user input are the same.
This is what I have now:
[code=vbnet] Private Sub ButtonGenerateWords_Click(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles ButtonGenerateWords.Click
ListBoxCombinations.Items.Clear()
Dim rnd As New Random()
' There are 125 combinations if all letters are different.
Do While ListBoxCombinations.Items.Count < 125
Dim word As String = Nothing
For i As Integer = 0 To 2
word &= AskWordCharacters()(rnd.Next(5))
Next
If Not ListBoxCombinations.Items.Contains(word) Then ListBoxCombinations.Items.Add(word)
Loop
End Sub
Private Function AskWordCharacters() As String()
Dim characters(4) As String
For i As Integer = 0 To TextBoxWord.Text.Trim().ToCharArray().Length - 1
characters(i) = TextBoxWord.Text.Trim().ToCharArray()(i)
Next
Return characters
End Function[/code]
Some logica geniuses that have a clue how to do this? Or at least help me on the way? Thanks in advance.

item.title: VB.NET Logica
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

I’m getting closer but I’m still stick with one thing.

This is my code now:

 Private Sub GenerateWords()

        ListBoxWords.Items.Clear()

        Dim letters(4) As String

        ' Put the user inputted letters in an array.

        For i As Integer = 0 To TextBoxWord.Text.Trim().ToCharArray().Length - 1

            letters(i) = TextBoxWord.Text.Trim().ToCharArray()(i)

        Next

        ' Loop 5 times (for 5 letters)

        For i As Integer = 0 To 4

            ' Loop 12 times (12 combinations)

            For j As Integer = 0 To 11

                ' Declaring a variable containing already the first letter.

                Dim word As String = letters(i)

                ' Loop 5 times (5 letters)

                For k As Integer = 0 To 4

                    ' If the letter is not equal to the first letter...

                    If letters(i) <> letters(k) Then

                        ' add the letter to the word.

                        word &= letters(k)

                    End If

                Next

                'Write the word to the listbox
                ListBoxWords.Items.Add(word)

                ' Move the letters a spot for the next combination.
                Dim firstChar As String = letters(0)

                letters(0) = letters(1)
                letters(1) = letters(2)
                letters(2) = letters(3)
                letters(3) = firstChar

            Next

        Next

    End Sub

It’s pretty obvious that my problem lays in this part of code:

[code=vbnet] ’ Move the letters a spot for the next combination.
Dim firstChar As String = letters(0)

            letters(0) = letters(1)
            letters(1) = letters(2)
            letters(2) = letters(3)
            letters(3) = firstChar[/code]

I’m only moving the letters a spot and not getting all the combinations.
I don’t really know how I could do this in a proper way yet, I’m trying to figure it out.
If anybody has a good idea let me know

Read full topic

item.title: VB.NET Logica
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“RandQm, post:12, topic:538024”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=656849.msg4395090#msg4395090 date=1388876633]

Do these have to be valid 3-letter words? Or if someone inputs ‘apple’ will ‘ppa’ be acceptable?

That’s what I meant earlier, I think RandQm misunderstood what I meant.

For “apple”, will the output be only “pal”, “ale”, “pea” and “ape” (and any others that I missed) or will the output be “app”, “apl”, “ape”, “pap”, “ppl”, “ple”, etc?

The 2nd one

I will tell you the steps. You, or someone else, can create an algorithm for it.

For character 0:

[ol][li]Print characters 0, 1, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 1, 3[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 1, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 2, 1[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 2, 3[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 2, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 3, 1[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 3, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 3, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 4, 1[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 4, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 4, 3[/li][/ol]

For character 1:

[ol][li]Print characters 1, 0, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 0, 3[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 0, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 2, 0[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 2, 3[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 2, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 3, 0[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 3, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 3, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 4, 0[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 4, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 4, 3[/li][/ol]

I’m sure you can see the pattern, creating an algorithm would be pretty simple.
[/quote]

Thanks a lot, I think I’m getting it.
Will let know once I worked on it, got some other primary stuff to do atm[/quote]

No problem As you can see, you just need to have a few nested for loops.

Read full topic

The 2nd one
[/quote]

I will tell you the steps. You, or someone else, can create an algorithm for it.

For character 0:

[ol][li]Print characters 0, 1, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 1, 3[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 1, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 2, 1[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 2, 3[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 2, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 3, 1[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 3, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 3, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 4, 1[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 4, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 0, 4, 3[/li][/ol]

For character 1:

[ol][li]Print characters 1, 0, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 0, 3[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 0, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 2, 0[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 2, 3[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 2, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 3, 0[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 3, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 3, 4[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 4, 0[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 4, 2[/li]
[li]Print characters 1, 4, 3[/li][/ol]

I’m sure you can see the pattern, creating an algorithm would be pretty simple. :)[/quote]

Thanks a lot, I think I’m getting it.
Will let know once I worked on it, got some other primary stuff to do atm

item.title: VB.NET Logica
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“RandQm, post:4, topic:538024”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=656849.msg4394831#msg4394831 date=1388794884]
How did you get 125 combinations? Shouldn’t it just be 5! = 120?
[/quote]

5^3 = 125[/quote]

Isn’t the number of ways to permute j distinct objects equal to j! via the multiplication principle?

Anyways, you’re right, it doesn’t really matter, since what you need help on is the program itself.

Best of luck!

Read full topic

item.title: VB.NET Logica
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

Svitkona:

Wouldn’t it just be 5c3 and not 5^3?

tbh it doesn’t matter what it is, since it’s not correct.
When 2 or more letters of the input are the same, the outcome will be different.
I wouldn’t ask for help if it was correct

item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

Jc22493:

How did you get 125 combinations? Shouldn’t it just be 5! = 120?

5^3 = 125

Ambokile:

Do they need to be dictionary words, or just 3-letter strings?

Make a program that allows the user to input a 5 letter-word.
When the user presses a button, the program must show in a textbox, all 3-letter word combinations that can be made with the 5 letters.

I’m betting it’s some kind of loopception that I’d need but I can’t figure something working out.

item.title: VB.NET Logica
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

I have to write a program that asks a 5-letter-word input to the user.
All the possible combinations of 3-letter-words made with the 5 letters of the the user input have to be displayed.

I can’t seem to get my head around the logica to do it. I’m now using randoms until the I have all the words.
But this is far from efficient and doesn’t work correctly when multiple letters of the user input are the same.

This is what I have now:

[code=vbnet] Private Sub ButtonGenerateWords_Click(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles ButtonGenerateWords.Click

    ListBoxCombinations.Items.Clear()

    Dim rnd As New Random()

    ' There are 125 combinations if all letters are different.

    Do While ListBoxCombinations.Items.Count < 125

        Dim word As String = Nothing

        For i As Integer = 0 To 2

            word &= AskWordCharacters()(rnd.Next(5))

        Next

        If Not ListBoxCombinations.Items.Contains(word) Then ListBoxCombinations.Items.Add(word)

    Loop

End Sub

Private Function AskWordCharacters() As String()

    Dim characters(4) As String

    For i As Integer = 0 To TextBoxWord.Text.Trim().ToCharArray().Length - 1

        characters(i) = TextBoxWord.Text.Trim().ToCharArray()(i)

    Next

    Return characters

End Function[/code]

Some logica geniuses that have a clue how to do this? Or at least help me on the way?
Thanks in advance.

Read full topic
